utterances: If I'm an Iraqi in Iraq and I want to get asylum into the U.S., what do I have to do?
What's the process?
Well, there is no way to get a refugee status when - while you're still inside Iraq.
For the moment, the administration is totally opposed to having any form of in-country processing.
So really, the only way would be to get out of the country and apply at one of the UNHCR offices, the High Commissioner for Refugees offices, in Jordan or Syria.
The problem, however, is that now Jordan has closed its borders and Syria has very recently closed its borders as well.
So, basically, people are now trapped.
They have no way out.
And if I've managed to get to one of those countries, at some point U.S.
screening comes in, security screening in particular.
Absolutely.
The first step is basically registration with the High Commissioner for Refugees offices.
Once they have determined that you are indeed a refugee and have a well-founded fear of persecution, they conduct several interviews to verify your stories, verify your contacts, et cetera.
Then when they decide that you are a candidate for resettlement based on several criteria for vulnerability, they refer you to embassy.
Once a refugee has been referred to a U.S.
embassy, he undergoes again a series of screenings from the Department of Homeland Security to check his information, et cetera.
It has to be said that coming in on a refugee visa to the United States is one of hardest ways to come into this country.

On the subject of plots, here's a pretty complicated one.
A woman watches the Gulf oil spill washing up on her doorstep.
Meanwhile, hundreds of miles away, a flood threatens her hometown.
Also, a friend of 30 years takes his own life and her child announces he's transgender, all in the course of one year.
Now, that's no novel.
It all actually happened to Gretchen Peters in 2010.
Some of us might crumble under the weight of so many life-changing events, but Peters was able to channel them.
The two-time Grammy nominated songwriter put pen to paper and wrote the album of her career.

Gretchen Peters' new album is called ""Hello Cruel World.
I sort of approached the writing on the album not in terms of so much writing, you know, here's a song about this, here's a song about the flood, and here's a song about my son and so forth.
It was more that the emotional earthquakes that were happening that year informed all of the songs.
But I will say that I certainly felt sort of raw and clarified, in a way, by all of these events, as major life events will do to you.
I felt that I was craving the truth.
And I wanted to tell the truth, and I wanted the truth to be, you know, brutally honest.

Well, I think what happens, you know, primarily, is a feeling of helplessness.
And it's like a huge reminder from the universe that you're not in control of anything, really.
And the flood in Nashville was devastating, but it was very fickle.

I mean, Nashville is a hilly place, and you could walk down one street and it would look completely normal, such as our street where our house is and literally turn the corner and another street would be under 20 feet of water.
And that was just so profoundly disorienting and horrifying to see.
And the oil spill, I'd hasten to say, was obviously not a natural disaster but a manmade one, but it was a similar feeling.
It was this feeling of utter helplessness, and it went on and on and on.
And I think it really did, though, more than anything for me, just reinforce the fact that we are not in control of our natural world or really anything.
And I wanted to explore that in these songs.
And certainly, that was what was coming out of me.
